message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The hypodermis is the deepest layer of skin, and invasion of this layer by malignant melanoma carries the highest risk of mortality. The other options are superficial layers of the skin and would not carry the same mortality risk.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The hypodermis or subcutaneous tissue is the deepest layer of skin and the invasion of malignant melanoma into this layer signifies a more advanced stage of the disease and a higher risk of mortality. Invasion of the other layers listed does not carry as high of a risk.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The highest risk of mortality for malignant melanoma is associated with invasion into the hypodermis, also known as subcutaneous tissue. Invasion into the papillary dermis also carries a high risk, but not as high as invasion into the hypodermis. Invasion into the stratum basale is considered to have a better prognosis, while invasion into the stratum corneum is not considered to be melanoma at all.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The deepest layer of the skin is the hypodermis and invasion of this layer carries the highest risk of mortality in patients with malignant melanoma. Invasion of the other layers may indicate different stages of the disease, but the hypodermis is the deepest layer and thus carries the highest risk.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The layer of skin that carries the highest risk of mortality for malignant melanoma is the hypodermis, which is the layer of skin that lies beneath the dermis and contains fat and connective tissue. The depth of invasion is measured in millimeters from the top of the stratum granulosum to the deepest point of invasion, and deeper invasion is associated with a higher risk of mortality.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Malignant melanoma originates from melanocytes in the basal layers of the epidermis and has the potential to invade deeply into the dermis and beyond. Invasion into the hypodermis carries the highest risk of mortality for the patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Based on the description of the mole, the diagnosis of malignant melanoma is confirmed by a full-thickness excisional biopsy. The highest risk of mortality is associated with invasion of the hypodermis. Options A, B, and D are not associated with melanoma metastasis or mortality risk.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The invasion of the hypodermis (subcutaneous fat layer) carries the highest risk of mortality for patients with malignant melanoma. The depth of invasion is measured in terms of Breslow thickness, with thicker tumors carrying a higher risk of mortality.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The hypodermis is the deepest layer of skin and invasion into this layer carries the highest risk of mortality in malignant melanoma. Additionally, the presence of ulceration also indicates a more aggressive melanoma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Melanoma that invades the hypodermis carries the highest risk of mortality. Options A, B, and D correspond to layers of the skin that are less deep and do not carry as high a risk of mortality.
